articles.title: Olympic Truce: ‘Humanity can find common ground through sport’
articles.summary: Sport has always been more than a contest of strength or skill. At its best, it becomes a rare space where people meet as equals – a reminder, as the President of the UN General Assembly put it on Wednesday, that “even in times of division, humanity can find common ground through sport – and an enduring hope.”
articles.content:
Speaking ahead of the Milano-Cortina 2026 Winter Olympics, Annalena Baerbock recalled her years as a young trampoline gymnast chasing the Olympic dream – and the sense of unity that sport can forge, even between rivals.

The Olympic Truce, she said, is a powerful symbol of that possibility – “a living metaphor of what peace requires: discipline, respect and courage needed to build peace.”

Examples from recent decades show how powerful that metaphor can be in practice.

In the 1990s, the Open Fun Football Schools brought together more than 150,000 children across ethnic divides in the Balkans, using play to rebuild trust after conflict.

Similar programmes in Colombia and Cyprus have helped fractured communities slowly rediscover confidence through shared games, shared goals, and shared ground.

UN Photo/Evan Schneider General Assembly President Annalena Baerbock (left) chairs the Sport for Development and Peace: Building a Peaceful and Better World through Sport and Olympic Ideal meeting.

Equality at home

Sport’s ability to break down barriers is not only about peace between nations – it is also about equality at home.

Tweet URL

Gender equality featured prominently in the Assembly President’s remarks. She celebrated the defiant spirit of Canada’s women’s hockey team, who claimed Olympic gold at Sochi 2014 and famously embraced the taunt “Play like a girl?” with the reply: Yes – “fast and strong like girls.”

Their message, she said, pushes back against the stereotypes that continue to limit women and girls far beyond sport.

Milano-Cortina 2026 is set to be the most gender-balanced Winter Games yet, with women expected to make up 47 per cent of the athletes.

Italian promise

Italy has committed to ensuring that the Games advance inclusion and accessibility both on and off the ice, supported by hundreds of planned legacy projects.

The Italian delegation also highlighted moments of extraordinary sportsmanship that embody the Olympic spirit, recalling the generosity of bobsledder Eugenio Monti, who famously lent his rivals equipment during the 1964 Innsbruck Games – an act that cost him victory that day but earned him lasting respect.

“Sport and the Olympic Games can provide a beacon of hope, an alternative to rivalry and division,” Italy’s representative said.

As the world looks towards the winter games, the UN’s message is simple: the values learned on the field – fairness, courage, teamwork – are the same values needed to build a more peaceful and inclusive world.

articles.summary:

articles.content:
Click to expand Image Activists carry a banner warning of efforts to dismantle environmental licensing requirements in Brazil. © 2025 Cesar Muñoz Acebes/Human Rights Watch

(Belém) – Brazil’s Congress should reject proposals to dismantle environmental licensing requirements and to revoke a plan to protect human rights defenders, Human Rights Watch said today. Instead, it should contribute to global efforts to curb climate change by approving the Escazú agreement.

“As the world comes together to tackle the climate crisis at COP30 in Brazil, its Congress is considering proposals that would exacerbate it,” said César Muñoz, Brazil director at Human Rights Watch. “Brazil’s elected leaders should protect basic rights, which are under threat from environmental degradation and global warming.”

Thousands of government officials, experts, journalists, environmental defenders, and representatives from nongovernmental organizations and business are gathered at the 30th annual United Nations climate summit (COP30), which runs through November 21, 2025, in the Brazilian city of Belém.

Meanwhile, in Brasilia, some lawmakers are promoting measures that would undermine the conference’s objectives, Human Rights Watch said.

The Senate announced a joint session of both chambers of the National Congress for November 27 to review the General Environmental Licensing Law. In July, lawmakers had approved the law, called the “devastation bill” by its opponents for eliminating environmental requirements and protections. In August, President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, signed the law, though he vetoed some problematic provisions.

Congress can override Lula’s vetoes by securing majorities in each house; 257 votes in the Chamber of Deputies and 41 in the Senate. Lawmakers could reinstate a vetoed provision that would allow those proposing small or medium sized projects with alleged small or medium environmental impact potential to obtain licenses simply by filling out an environmental adherence form, without any need for environmental impact assessments.

A study by the Climate Observatory, a coalition of Brazilian environmental organizations, found that among the projects that would be included in that category would be dams like the one that collapsed in Brumadinho on January 25, 2019, causing 270 deaths and very extensive environmental damage.

Congress could also reintroduce provisions that would reduce the protection of Indigenous and rural Afro-Brazilian communities whose territories have not been formally recognized by the authorities.

Congress is also considering at least seven proposals to suspend the National Plan to Protect Human Rights Defenders. Established by federal decree in November, the plan seeks to strengthen coordination of policies and programs to protect individual human rights defenders and communities under threat, and guarantees civil society participation in monitoring its implementation. Brazilian human rights organizations had been pressing successive governments to develop such a plan for 20 years.

In 2007, the government issued a decree that required the creation of the plan within 90 days, but it never happened. Ten years later, federal prosecutor Enrico Rodrigues de Freitas sued the federal government to force it to comply with the decree, and in 2021, in response, a federal court ordered the government to design the plan. In 2022, in the Sales Pimenta case, the Inter-American Court of Human Rights ordered Brazil to create a working group to develop actions to address the causes of violence against defenders.

The Brazilian government established the Sales Pimenta working group, whose members were authorities and civil society representatives in equal numbers, which drafted the plan. At a COP30 event on November 16, Rodrigues de Freitas said that suspension of the plan by Congress “would violate domestic and international judicial decisions.”

Congress should not just refrain from suspending the decree that established the plan, but the protection of rights defenders by turning the plan into a law Human Rights Watch said. The Sales Pimenta working group developed a draft bill with that goal, Rodrigues de Freitas said.

The human rights and citizenship minister, Macaé Evaristo, said at a COP30 event that 1,458 people are enrolled in the federal program to protect human rights defenders, many of whom defend land rights or the environment.

The Pastoral Land Commission, a nonprofit organization affiliated with the Catholic Church, reported that 13 people were killed in conflicts over the use of land and resources in 2024, while it had documented 272 death threats. The urgency of the plan was highlighted on November 16, when gunmen killed an Indigenous man and injured four others during an attack within an Indigenous territory that is in the process of being demarcated.

Ratification of the Escazú agreement, a landmark treaty for Latin American and Caribbean nations that advances the right to a healthy environment, would strengthen protection of environmental defenders, Human Rights Watch said. In addition, the treaty ensures access to information, public participation in decision-making, and pathways to prevent and redress environmental harm. The Chamber of Deputies approved it on November 5, and it is pending before the Senate.

“Brazil’s Congress should open its eyes to the enormous impact of environmental destruction on the lives of millions of Brazilians and of violence against defenders,” Muñoz said. “Members of Congress should send a signal to Brazilians and to the world by approving the Escazú agreement.”
articles.reasoning: The article highlights an ongoing effort to protect environmental and human rights defenders in Brazil through a national plan and the Escazú agreement, which would have broad positive impacts on environmental protection, indigenous rights, and human rights. articles.personality_title: Brazil urged to protect environment and human rights defenders amid climate talks
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Brazil is hosting the 30th United Nations climate summit (COP30) in Belém, where thousands of experts and leaders have gathered to discuss climate change. At the same time, Brazil’s Congress is debating laws that could reduce environmental protections and threaten a plan to protect human rights defenders.

**What happened** – Human Rights Watch called on Brazil’s Congress to reject proposals that would weaken environmental licensing rules and suspend the National Plan to Protect Human Rights Defenders. The Congress is considering reinstating parts of a law that allows small and medium projects to get environmental licenses without proper impact studies. This could include dangerous projects like dams similar to the one that collapsed in Brumadinho in 2019. Lawmakers are also reviewing proposals that could reduce protections for Indigenous and Afro-Brazilian communities. Meanwhile, the Congress is deciding whether to approve the Escazú agreement, a treaty that supports environmental rights and protects people who defend the environment.

**Impact** – Weakening environmental rules risks more damage like the Brumadinho dam disaster, which killed 270 people and caused severe harm. Cutting protections for human rights defenders could increase violence against those who protect land and nature. The National Plan to Protect Human Rights Defenders, created after years of pressure and court orders, currently helps over 1,400 people at risk. Approving the Escazú agreement would improve access to environmental information, involve the public in decisions, and offer legal tools to prevent harm. This treaty is seen as a key step to protect both the environment and the people defending it.

**What's next step** – The Congress will hold a joint session on November 27 to review the environmental licensing law and decide on the future of the human rights defenders’ plan. The Senate still needs to approve the Escazú agreement after the Chamber of Deputies passed it in early November. Human Rights Watch and others hope lawmakers will strengthen protections by turning the defenders’ plan into law and fully supporting the Escazú treaty.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Brazil’s lawmakers face a critical choice to protect the environment and human rights defenders or risk worsening climate damage and violence during a key global summit.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Brésil appelé à protéger l’environnement et les défenseurs des droits humains lors du sommet climatique
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Brésil accueille le 30e sommet climatique des Nations Unies (COP30) à Belém, où des milliers d’experts et de dirigeants se réunissent pour discuter du changement climatique. En même temps, le Congrès brésilien débat de lois qui pourraient réduire les protections environnementales et menacer un plan de protection des défenseurs des droits humains.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Human Rights Watch a demandé au Congrès brésilien de rejeter des propositions affaiblissant les règles de licence environnementale et suspendant le Plan national de protection des défenseurs des droits humains. Le Congrès envisage de réintroduire des parties d’une loi permettant à des projets petits ou moyens d’obtenir des licences sans études d’impact environnemental. Cela pourrait inclure des projets dangereux comme des barrages similaires à celui qui s’est effondré à Brumadinho en 2019. Les députés examinent aussi des propositions réduisant la protection des communautés indigènes et afro-brésiliennes. Par ailleurs, le Congrès doit décider d’approuver l’accord d’Escazú, un traité qui soutient les droits environnementaux et protège les défenseurs de l’environnement.

**Impact** – Affaiblir les règles environnementales risque de provoquer d’autres catastrophes comme Brumadinho, qui a causé 270 morts et de graves dégâts. Réduire la protection des défenseurs des droits humains pourrait aggraver la violence contre ceux qui protègent la terre et la nature. Le Plan national de protection, créé après des années de pression et d’ordres judiciaires, aide actuellement plus de 1 400 personnes en danger. L’adoption de l’accord d’Escazú améliorerait l’accès à l’information environnementale, impliquerait le public dans les décisions et offrirait des moyens juridiques pour prévenir les dommages. Ce traité est une étape clé pour protéger l’environnement et ceux qui le défendent.

**Prochaine étape** – Le Congrès tiendra une session conjointe le 27 novembre pour revoir la loi sur les licences environnementales et décider de l’avenir du plan de protection des défenseurs. Le Sénat doit encore approuver l’accord d’Escazú après son adoption par la Chambre des députés début novembre. Human Rights Watch et d’autres espèrent que les législateurs renforceront les protections en transformant le plan en loi et en soutenant pleinement le traité.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Les législateurs brésiliens doivent choisir entre protéger l’environnement et les défenseurs des droits humains ou risquer d’aggraver les dégâts climatiques et la violence lors d’un sommet mondial crucial.
articles.personality_title_es: Brasil instado a proteger el medio ambiente y a defensores de derechos humanos en cumbre climática
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Brasil está organizando la 30ª cumbre climática de las Naciones Unidas (COP30) en Belém, donde miles de expertos y líderes se reúnen para hablar sobre el cambio climático. Al mismo tiempo, el Congreso de Brasil debate leyes que podrían reducir las protecciones ambientales y amenazar un plan para proteger a los defensores de los derechos humanos.

**Qué pasó** – Human Rights Watch pidió al Congreso brasileño que rechace propuestas que debilitarían las normas de licencias ambientales y suspenderían el Plan Nacional para Proteger a los Defensores de los Derechos Humanos. El Congreso está considerando reinstaurar partes de una ley que permitiría a proyectos pequeños y medianos obtener licencias sin estudios de impacto ambiental. Esto podría incluir proyectos peligrosos como represas similares a la que colapsó en Brumadinho en 2019. También revisan propuestas que reducirían la protección a comunidades indígenas y afrobrasileñas. Además, el Congreso debe decidir si aprueba el acuerdo de Escazú, un tratado que apoya los derechos ambientales y protege a quienes defienden el medio ambiente.

**Impacto** – Debilitar las normas ambientales podría causar más desastres como Brumadinho, que causó 270 muertes y daños graves. Reducir la protección a defensores de derechos humanos podría aumentar la violencia contra quienes protegen la tierra y la naturaleza. El Plan Nacional de Protección, creado tras años de presión y órdenes judiciales, actualmente protege a más de 1,400 personas en riesgo. Aprobar el acuerdo de Escazú mejoraría el acceso a la información ambiental, permitiría la participación pública en decisiones y ofrecería herramientas legales para prevenir daños. Este tratado es un paso importante para proteger el medio ambiente y sus defensores.

**Próximo paso** – El Congreso realizará una sesión conjunta el 27 de noviembre para revisar la ley de licencias ambientales y decidir sobre el futuro del plan de protección. El Senado aún debe aprobar el acuerdo de Escazú, tras su paso por la Cámara de Diputados a principios de noviembre. Human Rights Watch y otros esperan que los legisladores fortalezcan las protecciones convirtiendo el plan en ley y apoyando completamente el tratado.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Los legisladores brasileños enfrentan una decisión crucial para proteger el medio ambiente y a los defensores de derechos humanos o arriesgar un mayor daño climático y violencia durante una cumbre global clave.

articles.title: Ending violence against women ‘a matter of dignity, equality and human rights’
articles.summary: When Salma* was just 15, she was forced to get married, even though she wanted to stay in school and become a doctor someday.
articles.content:
Instead, she found herself tied to a man who “changed from being kind to being a monster.” He would beat her “with his bare hands,” she said recently.

The young mother from Yemen is among the roughly 840 million women worldwide – nearly one in three – who have faced physical or sexual violence at the hands of an intimate partner, such as a former or current husband.

Even worse, this figure has barely changed since the year 2000, with a paltry 0.2 per cent annual decline over the past two decades.

In the last 12 months alone, 11 per cent of women aged 15 or older, some 316 million, were subjected to physical or sexual violence by an intimate partner.

Tweet URL

A ‘pervasive’ injustice

“Violence against women is one of humanity’s oldest and most pervasive injustices, yet still one of the least acted upon,” said Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, Director-General of the World Health Organization (WHO).

The lack of progress is documented in a report published on Wednesday by WHO and other UN agencies.

It analyses data from 168 countries, covering the period from 2000 to 2023, revealing “a stark picture of a deeply neglected crisis and critically underfunded response.”

For the first time, national and regional estimates of sexual violence by someone other than a partner – a male relative or friend, for example – are included.

Findings show that 263 million women have experienced non-partner sexual violence since age 15, a figure experts caution is significantly under-reported due to stigma and fear.

Funding shortfall persists

WHO noted that despite mounting evidence of effective strategies for the prevention of violence against women, financial support continues to be slashed.

In 2022, only 0.2 per cent of global development aid went to these programmes, and funding has fallen further.

This is happening at a time when humanitarian emergencies, rising inequality and other challenges are putting millions of women and girls at risk.

Violence begins early

Women subjected to violence face unintended pregnancies, a higher risk of acquiring sexually transmitted infections and experiencing depression, according to the report.

Furthermore, violence against women begins early, and risks persist throughout life. In the past 12 months alone, 12.5 million young women aged 15-19 have experienced physical and/or sexual violence from an intimate partner.

“The data shows that many women first experience violence from a partner when they are adolescents. And many children grow up watching their mothers being pushed, hit or humiliated, with violence a part of daily life,” said Catherine Russell, Executive Director of the child rights agency UNICEF.

The key is to break this pattern, she added.

Action, support and investment

The report was released ahead of the International Day for the Elimination of Violence against Women and Girls, observed annually on 25 November.

It calls for decisive government action and funding to scale-up evidenced-based prevention programmes and to strengthen health, legal and social services for survivors.

Countries must also invest in data systems to track progress and reach those groups most at risk, in addition to enforcing laws and policies that empower women and girls.

“No society can call itself fair, safe or healthy while half its population lives in fear,” said Tedros.

“Ending this violence is not only a matter of policy; it is a matter of dignity, equality and human rights.”

Salma’s dream

Salma* is now back at school, after a judge eventually released her to her parents.

She was also referred to safe space supported by the UN reproductive agency, UNFPA, where she learned about her rights, and stands firm in her dream to become a doctor.

“We must act urgently together to end this violence and ensure that every woman and girl, in all her diversity, can exercise her rights, realize her potential and contribute fully to more just, equal and prosperous societies,” said Diene Keita, UNFPA Executive Director.

*Name changed for protection.

It presents a meaningful human rights issue with broad societal impact and includes concrete data and recommendations, as well as an inspiring personal story of recovery and hope.
articles.personality_title: New report urges urgent action to end violence against women worldwide
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Around one in three women globally have experienced violence from a partner, a problem that has barely improved in over 20 years. Many cases remain hidden due to fear and stigma.

**What happened** – The World Health Organization (WHO) and UN agencies released a report analyzing data from 168 countries between 2000 and 2023. It highlights the ongoing crisis of physical and sexual violence against women, including new estimates of violence from non-partners. The report also shows that funding for prevention programs is very low and has decreased.

**Impact** – This report is important because it reveals how widespread and persistent violence against women is, starting often in teenage years, and how little progress has been made. It shows that millions of women suffer serious health and emotional harm. The data provides clear evidence that more support and stronger laws are needed to protect women and girls.

**What's next step** – The report calls for governments to increase funding for prevention and survivor support programs, improve data collection, and enforce laws that empower women. It encourages urgent, coordinated action to break the cycle of violence and help survivors rebuild their lives.

**One-sentence takeaway** – A new global report exposes ongoing violence against women and demands stronger action and investment to protect their rights and safety.
articles.personality_title_fr: Un nouveau rapport demande une action urgente pour mettre fin à la violence contre les femmes dans le monde
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Environ une femme sur trois dans le monde a subi des violences de la part d’un partenaire, un problème qui a peu évolué depuis plus de 20 ans. Beaucoup de cas restent cachés par peur et honte.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – L’Organisation mondiale de la santé (OMS) et des agences de l’ONU ont publié un rapport analysant des données de 168 pays de 2000 à 2023. Il souligne la crise persistante des violences physiques et sexuelles contre les femmes, y compris des nouvelles estimations sur les violences commises par des personnes autres que le partenaire. Le rapport montre aussi que les financements pour la prévention sont très faibles et ont diminué.

**Impact** – Ce rapport est important car il révèle à quel point la violence contre les femmes est répandue et persistante, souvent dès l’adolescence, et combien peu de progrès ont été réalisés. Il montre que des millions de femmes subissent des dommages graves à leur santé et à leur bien-être. Ces données montrent clairement qu’il faut plus de soutien et de lois fortes pour protéger les femmes et les filles.

**Prochaine étape** – Le rapport appelle les gouvernements à augmenter les financements pour les programmes de prévention et d’aide aux victimes, à améliorer la collecte de données et à appliquer des lois qui renforcent les droits des femmes. Il encourage une action urgente et coordonnée pour briser le cycle de la violence et aider les survivantes à reconstruire leur vie.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Un nouveau rapport mondial révèle la violence persistante contre les femmes et demande plus d’action et d’investissements pour protéger leurs droits et leur sécurité.
articles.personality_title_es: Nuevo informe pide acción urgente para acabar con la violencia contra las mujeres en el mundo
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Cerca de una de cada tres mujeres en el mundo ha sufrido violencia por parte de su pareja, un problema que ha cambiado muy poco en más de 20 años. Muchos casos no se denuncian por miedo y vergüenza.

**Qué pasó** – La Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS) y agencias de la ONU publicaron un informe con datos de 168 países entre 2000 y 2023. El informe destaca la crisis continua de violencia física y sexual contra las mujeres, incluyendo nuevas cifras sobre violencia de personas que no son parejas. También muestra que la financiación para programas de prevención es muy baja y ha disminuido.

**Impacto** – Este informe es importante porque muestra cuán común y persistente es la violencia contra las mujeres, que muchas veces comienza en la adolescencia, y que se ha avanzado poco. Revela que millones de mujeres sufren graves daños físicos y emocionales. Los datos muestran claramente la necesidad de más apoyo y leyes más fuertes para proteger a mujeres y niñas.

**Próximos pasos** – El informe pide a los gobiernos que aumenten la financiación para programas de prevención y apoyo a las víctimas, mejoren la recolección de datos y apliquen leyes que empoderen a las mujeres. Llama a una acción urgente y coordinada para romper el ciclo de violencia y ayudar a las sobrevivientes a reconstruir sus vidas.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Un nuevo informe mundial revela la violencia persistente contra las mujeres y exige mayor acción e inversión para proteger sus derechos y seguridad.
